speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: SCENE IV. Plains between Troy and the Grecian camp.

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Alarums: excursions. Enter THERSITES

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Now they are clapper-clawing one another; I'll go

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: look on. That dissembling abominable varlets Diomed,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: has got that same scurvy doting foolish young knave's

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: sleeve of Troy there in his helm: I would fain see

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: them meet; that that same young Trojan ass, that

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: loves the whore there, might send that Greekish

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: whore-masterly villain, with the sleeve, back to the

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: dissembling luxurious drab, of a sleeveless errand.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: O' the t'other side, the policy of those crafty

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: swearing rascals, that stale old mouse-eaten dry

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: cheese, Nestor, and that same dog-fox, Ulysses, is

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: not proved worthy a blackberry: they set me up, in

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: policy, that mongrel cur, Ajax, against that dog of

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: as bad a kind, Achilles: and now is the cur Ajax

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: prouder than the cur Achilles, and will not arm

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: to-day; whereupon the Grecians begin to proclaim

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: barbarism, and policy grows into an ill opinion.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Soft! here comes sleeve, and t'other.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter DIOMEDES, TROILUS following

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: Fly not; for shouldst thou take the river Styx,

speaker: TROILUS
text_entry: I would swim after.

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Thou dost miscall retire:

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: I do not fly, but advantageous care

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Withdrew me from the odds of multitude:

speaker: DIOMEDES
text_entry: Have at thee!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Hold thy whore, Grecian!--now for thy whore,

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Trojan!--now the sleeve, now the sleeve!

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Exeunt TROILUS and DIOMEDES, fighting

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Enter HECTOR

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: What art thou, Greek? art thou for Hector's match?

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Art thou of blood and honour?

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: No, no, I am a rascal; a scurvy railing knave:

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: a very filthy rogue.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: I do believe thee: live.

speaker: HECTOR
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: God-a-mercy, that thou wilt believe me; but a

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: plague break thy neck for frightening me! What's

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: become of the wenching rogues? I think they have

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: swallowed one another: I would laugh at that

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: miracle: yet, in a sort, lechery eats itself.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: I'll seek them.

speaker: THERSITES
text_entry: Exit
